section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Alphabet Cards

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the story, Ready, Set, Build! We found rhyming words and words with letters we know.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Review Ss, Ff, Pp Alphabet Cards Let’s look at some letters you have learned. This is uppercase S. This is lowercase s. The letter s makes the sound you hear at the beginning of sun and socks. Repeat with letter Ff in fish and fox and letter Pp in penguin and peach.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When two words rhyme, they end with the same sounds, like dig and rig or space and race.
Here are some picture cards. We will say the word for each picture and split the word into beginning and ending sounds. Then we will sort the cards by beginning sounds and by rhymes.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Lay Alphabet Cards Ss, Ff, and Pp in a row on a table. Set the activity cards in a pile, picture side up.

Ask Invite a child to pick a card. Ask the child to say the word for the picture and split the word into onset and rime. Have the child set the card beneath the letter card that matches the word’s beginning sound.
Repeat Repeat with another child until all activity cards are sorted.
Play Again Repeat. This time, help children sort the words into pairs by rhyme (saw/paw, fox/socks, fan/pan, fin/pin).

Practice Writing Ask children to choose their favorite word from the activity to write. Model writing the word, saying each letter sound and demonstrating how to form each letter as you write it. Then have children write the word.

If children need help dividing words into onset and rime, model it for them: fox, /f/ /oks/, fox. Then ask, What is the beginning sound in fox, /f/ or /oks/? What is the ending sound in fox, /f/ or /oks/?
Challenge children to name as many additional words as they can that begin with s /s/, f /f/, and p /p/. Then have them think of additional words that rhyme with each rhyming pair from the activity.

Invite multilingual learners to share words from their home language that have the same beginning sound as or rhyme with words in the activity. This exchange will benefit all children since the concepts of letter sounds and rhyme are not language-specific but rather sound-specific. It is beneficial to all children to practice letter sounds and rhyming words, including words from another language!

To help children struggling with auditory discrimination identify onset and rime, emphasize each sound, exaggerating the movements of your mouth, and being mindful of your tongue and lip positions. Do this while saying onset and rime in isolation and again as you say the whole word. Invite children to move their mouths in the same way as they say the sounds.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the story Ready, Set, Build! about a dog and bird who help one another to build a house. We thought about how the dog and the bird were feeling.
When we show empathy, we notice and ask how others are feeling. We offer help and support when others need it.
In this activity we will practice showing empathy by asking how someone is feeling.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Place the cards face down.

Ask Invite two children to play. Ask one child to pick a card and identify the emotion in the picture. Have the second child ask, “How are you feeling?” The first child should answer with the emotion on the card. Then have the partners switch roles, with the second child choosing a new card and the first child asking the question.
Repeat Continue the activity, reusing cards as needed, until all children in the group have had the opportunity to play both roles.

Talk About Feelings and Help Discuss the emotion on each card. Invite children to share what might make someone feel happy, mad, or sad, using examples from their own experience as appropriate. Ask children to share what they need or want when they feel each emotion (examples: a hug; help solving a problem; a friend to play with).

Extend Invite children to consider the question, “How can I help?” Discuss ways we can help people when they are feeling sad or mad. Then invite children to take turns acting out helping a friend who has one of those feelings.

If children need help identifying the emotion on the card, name the emotion and model it for them with exaggerated facial expressions. Then have them practice modeling the same facial expressions with you.
Challenge children to name other emotions, such as frightened, nervous, excited, and silly, and ask them to show on their faces what those feelings look like.

Invite multilingual learners to name the emotions in their home language and then in English. Using both visual supports and physical activities such as modeling emotions are especially beneficial to help children acquire vocabulary in a new language.

When children have trouble identifying the emotions of others, they can also have trouble identifying social cues and modifying their behavior in social situations. Try sitting in front of a mirror with a child so that you can see one another’s faces. Say the name of the emotion and make the appropriate expression. Have the child use the mirror to make his or her face have the same expression. If possible, display the mirror in the classroom so that children can have fun practicing making and identifying emotions with friends.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Poster board, drawing supplies

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read Ready, Set, Build! The dog and the bird in the story do lots of things to stay safe while they are building a house.
When we stay safe, we do things in a certain way to make sure we don’t hurt ourselves or others. What are some ways we can stay safe?
Today we will have a conversation about how we stay safe every day in our classroom. We will use words we know about safety to make a safety poster.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Set up a large poster board on a table or wall. Have markers available for writing. Have paper and crayons for children.

Ask Ask children what they know about safety rules in the classroom. Encourage them to engage in extended conversation by asking “why” and “what if” questions. (Why can’t we run? What happens if we don’t wash our hands?)
Write On the poster board, write three classroom safety rules that came from the conversation. Read them aloud. Have children sign the poster with their name or their initials.
Extend Invite each child to choose one safety rule to illustrate.
Share Invite children to share their drawings with a partner. Have them ask, “How does your drawing show how to stay safe?”
Display Display children’s drawings with the safety poster.

To encourage extended discussion and give support, provide children with specific situational examples, such as, “Where do we put our trash? What could happen if we didn’t put our trash in the trash can?”
Challenge children to imagine what would happen if there were no safety rules in the classroom. Have them share their thoughts as part of the discussion.

Extended conversation plays a critical role in helping multilingual learners to acquire a new language. One way to support children is by using oral conversation frames that repeat part of the question in the answer. For example: What is one safety rule? One safety rule is “no running.” Have children say the frames with you. Then have partners use the frames to ask and answer questions with each other.

Many preschool-age children have trouble maintaining attention through an extended conversation. Use a “talking turn” object such as a rock, ball, or stuffed animal. Only the child with the object can speak. When the child is done, the object is handed to the next child. For children who like to move, this can be made into an active game. Use a ball and allow the child to roll it to the next speaker.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Alphabet Cards, drawing supplies

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the story The Three Little Rabbits. Who can remember what the rabbits used to build their houses? Who can remember what the strongest material was?

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-card_run-in_hed: Review Ss, Ff, Pp Alphabet Cards
ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Who can remember each letter we’re reviewing this week? Can you think of a word that starts with the letter s? The letter f? The letter p?

In this activity, we will think about other materials the rabbits could have used instead of straw, sticks, and bricks. Here’s our challenge: the rabbits can only use materials that start with the letters s, f, or p.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Make a chart with three columns. Title each column with the letters S, F, and P. Write sand, foam, and paper where appropriate.

Ask Encourage children to think of other materials that start with the letters s, f, or p. Let children think creatively and emphasize that the materials don’t have to be typical building materials. One rabbit could build his house with strawberries! Write down children’s suggestions when they correctly name words that begin with s, f, and p.
Plan Provide drawing supplies. Invite children to draw a house one of the rabbits could build made of a material that they choose.
Practice Writing the Letters Ss, Ff, and Pp Encourage children to write the name of the material they chose underneath their house. Then have children practice forming the letters Ss, Ff, and Pp.

Provide multiple examples of possible building materials for each letter, such as “Does popcorn start with p? Can the rabbits use popcorn to build a house? What do you think a house of popcorn would look like? Can you draw it?”

Challenge children to rewrite the story of The Three Little Rabbits, using the new materials suggested. Ask them to consider how the new materials would affect the outcome of the story. Invite children to illustrate scenes of their story.

When reviewing the letter sounds for Ss, Ff, and Pp by saying different possible building materials that begin with those sounds, always respond by repeating the letter sound and name. For example, after a child answers that soap begins with /s/, say “Yes, soap begins with /s/. The S stands for the sound /s/.” Hold up the Ss Alphabet Card.

Have children stand up and act out The Three Little Rabbits. Have children pretend to build their houses with materials of their choice. Then have children pretend to try to blow their houses down. Did their houses fall?
